import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# ta dando um warning na plotagem do pie plot
# investigar dpois
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

sns.set_context("paper")
sns.set_style("darkgrid")
sns.set_palette('RdYlGn')

              data=df,
              ax=_[0][1],
              order=['group A', 'group B', 'group C', 'group D', 'group E'])

              ax=_[1][0],
              order=['some college', 'some high school', 'high school', "associate's degree", "bachelor's degree", "master's degree"])

_[1][0].set_ylabel('')

              data=df,
              ax=_[1][1])

plt.show()

df.head()
source.4b589ccc:
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = [15, 6]

fig, _ = plt.subplots(1,2)

sns.boxplot(x='parental level of education',
            y='general mean',
            data=df,
            order=['some college', 'some high school', 'high school', "associate's degree", "bachelor's degree", "master's degree"],
            ax=_[0])

_[0].tick_params('x', labelrotation=45)

df_grouped_median = df.groupby('parental level of education')['general mean'].median()

sns.pointplot(x=df_grouped_median.index,
              y=df_grouped_median.values,
              order=['some college', 'some high school', 'high school', "associate's degree", "bachelor's degree", "master's degree"],
              ax=_[1])

_[1].tick_params('x', labelrotation=45)

plt.suptitle("Does the academic level of the parents influence the students' average score?")

plt.show()

source.ae8496a3:
fig, _ = plt.subplots(1,2)

gped_median_educ_gender = df.groupby(['parental level of education', 'gender'])['general mean'].median().reset_index()

sns.pointplot(x='parental level of education',
              y='general mean',
              hue='gender',
              data=gped_median_educ_gender,
              order=['some college', 'some high school', 'high school', "associate's degree", "bachelor's degree", "master's degree"],
              ax=_[0])

_[0].title.set_text("Does the academic level of the parents influence the students' average score? (by gender)")
_[0].tick_params('x', labelrotation=45)

gped_median_race_gender = df.groupby(['race/ethnicity', 'gender'])['general mean'].median().reset_index()

sns.pointplot(x='race/ethnicity',
              y='general mean',
              hue='gender',
              data=gped_median_race_gender,
              order=['group A', 'group B', 'group C', 'group D', 'group E'],
              ax=_[1])

_[1].title.set_text("Does the student's race / ethnicity influence his average score? (by gender)")
_[1].tick_params('x', labelrotation=45)

plt.show()
source.7ef1f032:
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = [15, 10]

f, _ = plt.subplots(2,3)

def plot_pie(gped_df, group, ax, f_n, s_n):
    
    gped_df.xs(group).plot(kind='pie', autopct='%1.0f%%', ax=ax[f_n][s_n])
    
    ax[f_n][s_n].title.set_text(group)

plot_pie(gped_race_testprep, 'group A', _, 0, 0)
plot_pie(gped_race_testprep, 'group B', _, 0, 1)
plot_pie(gped_race_testprep, 'group C', _, 0, 2)
plot_pie(gped_race_testprep, 'group D', _, 1, 0)
plot_pie(gped_race_testprep, 'group E', _, 1, 1)

_[1][2].set_visible(False)

plt.suptitle('What percentage of students study before the exam in each ethnic group?')

plt.show()

source.f2900d64: #### There's any correlation between parental level of education and race?
source.e5993f49:
• Students who have parents with incomplete high school usually prepare for exams (more than the others).
  • Students who have parents with bachelor's degree usually prepare for exams.
  • Students who have parents with complete high school do not usually prepare for exams.
source.a796b878: #### Does the academic level of the parents influence the students' average score?
source.daaff3c0: • There's nowhere to run. If you want to have a good score, you have to take the preparatory course.
source.4d889d63: #### Who did the test preparatory course do better or worse in the scores than those who didn't?
source.d5b40a98: #### What percentage of students study before the exam in each ethnic group?
source.cf63c0fe: #### Students who have parents with little schooling usually prepare for exams?
source.73b74b38:
• Yep, that's right. Those who do well in reading, usually do well in writing too.
  • But those who do well in reading and writing, generally do not do well in mathematics.
source.1262f737:
• Students of race/ethnicity in group E have better averages than the others.
  • Students of race/ethnicity in group A have worse averages than the others.
source.b738541a: #### Is there any relationship between the scores? That is, who has a good reading score, does well in writing?
source.70e881f8:
• Students with parents with master's degrees have higher average scores than the rest.
  • Students with parents between some high school and high school are the ones with the worst averages in the scores.
source.0ec05da7: #### We will now analyze academic performance by gender. What is the overall performance for each discipline?
source.3127483e: Let's generate another column, called **general mean**. It will keep the overall average of each student (sum of the scores divided by 3).

source.d171ac0b:
# Students Performance in Exams (Correlations Analysis)

Good morning, Good afternoon or Good night! This notebook aims to discover possible correlations between variables and to investigate what else can affect the overall performance of students in the database. Any tip, or suggestion I am open to receive. Thanks!
source.fc6330fb:
~this was a nice plot~
  • Now we can see how the genders correlation between the scores!
source.10c5c223:
• There are more women than men at school
  • The predominant race/ethnicity is C, followed by D and B. A and E are a minority.
  • Most student parents have little academic knowledge (some college) or just some specialization (associate's degree).
  • Most use standard lunch.
source.6f9c12ed:
• Women are superior in scores in almost all scenarios.
  • In the race/ethnicity of group E, the scores of both genders are very similar.
source.137d2e54:
• Students from the ethnic group E are the most prepared for the exams. Because of this, their score is higher.
  • The group that least prepares for the exams is group D. However, they have the second highest average of ethnic groups.
source.73ea0a38: • The reason why the group D have the second highest average of ethnic groups, maybe it's because their parents have master's degree.
source.fe4914c1:
• Men have a higher average score than women in mathematics.
  • Women have a higher average score than men in reading and writing.
